SU BJ ECTIVE

REASON FOR VISIT: F/U for left middle finger pain

Jeremy Clements is a 29 year-old male here today for a work related left middle finger concern.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Clements returns to clinic regarding his left middle finger injury sustained on 4/20/2020. He‘s roughly 3
months out. The steroid shot helped. He‘s still having some soreness in the left hand. He‘s still working.
His main complaint now is around the Pleoint of the left middle finger. He complains to pain but no
triggering.

I decided to obtain and review old records, including charts available in the EMR, in preparation for the
visit. A 10+ review of systems and PSFH is available in the patient record and relevant findings were
incorporated into the histow of present illness. All other ROS systems are negative/noncontributory.

OBJECTIVE
Ht 5‘11.5“ /\/\/t 237 lbs / BMI 32.6

LEFT HAND AND WRIST EXAM
Inspection: Fingers are pink and well-perfused and no active triggering
Tenderness to Palpation: Tenderness over middle finger A1 pulley with palpable nodule and no
tenderness over the sagittal bands ofthe middle finger MCP joint
Neurovascular: Sensation intact to light touch throughout and brisk capillary refill
Stability:
No EDC subluxation

IMAGING
4/23/2020: Left hand x-ray at this clinic was ordered, taken, and reviewed by me. 3 views demonstrate no

fractures or dislocations and well-aligned MCP joint of the left middle finger.

ASSESSMENT AN D PLAN

IMPRESSION:

29 year-old gentleman with left middle finger radial sagittal band injury, improving with early trigger digit

PLAN

We discussed Mr. Clements‘s findings and discussed treatment options. I offered him a left middle finger
trigger digit injection. We discussed the risks and benefits of that. He desired to proceed and tolerated that
well. We‘re going to advance him to full duty. I‘m going to see him back in about 4-5 weeks for repeat
examination. N0 x-rays needed.

FOLLOW-UP: 4-6 weeks or earlier if symptoms change, fail to improve, worsen, or if any additional
questions need to be answered.

PROCEDU RE NOTES

INJECTION NOTE: The risks, benefits, and alternatives of steroid injection therapy were discussed with
the patient. For the LEFT MIDDLE FINGER: Risks include (but are not limited to) blood sugar elevation,
infection, allergic reaction, bleeding, fat necrosis, hematoma formation and skin pigment changes. The
patient understood and wished to continue. His allergies, past medical history, and medications were
reviewed.

The steroid solution was drawn up which consisted of 1.5 cc of 6 mg/cc Celestone. The skin was prepped
in the usual, sterile fashion using alcohol. The surrounding bony landmarks and the injection portal were
identified. The skin was then anesthetized with 1.5 cc Xylocaine. Using strict aseptic technique, the steroid
solution was then administered into the LEFT MIDDLE FINGER A1 pulley without significant resistance.

He tolerated the procedure well without complaints or apparent complications and the area was cleaned
and dressed. Return precautions were provided and the patient voiced understanding. He had no further
questions or concerns.

Any questions were answered. The patient demonstrated understanding and is agreeable with the
recommendations as discussed.

WORKERS‘ COMPENSATION

Claim Number: BLWC192572001
Date of Injury (DOI): 04/21/2020
